title: Applying data ethics
body:
In this module we will explore the application of data ethics using tools that support individuals and organisations in developing products and services that mitigate negative risks and serve to promote positive outcomes for people and society. 

This module provides you with the knowledge and skills to:

  1. Describe the types of questions to ask when embedding ethical data practices

  2. Identify common barriers to adopting approaches to data ethics

  3. Explain how to use tools and frameworks to support ethical thinking around collection, use and sharing of data in projects

  4. Make several recommendations to improve the ethical handling of data

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

title: Summary: what have we learned?
body:
Applied Data Ethics is the practice of evaluating our data practices to understand the impact of our work. This module has introduced tools that help us evaluate ethical data practices at the project level, and at the organisational level. Engaging with these tools is unlikely to remove all of the negative impacts that result from collecting, using and sharing data (or lack-of). However, they will support individuals and organisations to mitigate the negative consequences and promote more positive outcomes. 

When evaluating ethical risk, it is also important to evaluate the risk of NOT doing something. For example, what is the ethical risk of not developing a product for a specific purpose? What is the ethical risk of not sharing data with others? What is the ethical risk of not collecting data from a wide variety of different groups in society and only focusing on one?

Most importantly, make time for ethics. Invest in people, policies and processes. Also be prepared to adapt. Society changes, as will what is ethical and not. Only this investment and ability to adapt will help organisations demonstrate they are committed to their individual and organisational principles.

title: Q: Ethics and data governance
body: In addition to practical tools, what else do organisations need to provide in order to ensure data ethics is prioritised?

_items.text: Clear roles and responsibilities to manage data ethics concerns
Policies and processes that ensure data ethics is embedded in the organisation
Training for staff on how to evaluate data ethics concerns throughout the data lifecycle
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

In order to ensure data ethics is prioritised, organisations should treat it much like compliance/legal concerns and invest in people, policies and processes as well as training; tools are useless if no one takes responsibility for ensuring they are used and findings acted upon. This means that there must be clear roles and responsibilities linked to data ethics, policies and processes that ensure ethics is a primary concern throughout the data lifecycle, and training to support staff to follow policies and processes and make use of tools.

title: Q: Why do projects fail?
body: Which of the following is the primary reason that data projects fail?

_items.text: Lack of data
Issues with people and culture
Lack of processes
Lack of technology

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

63% of data project failures are due to issues with people and culture (McKinsey, 2018)

In short, if you can get people on board, you are much more likely to have positive outcomes for your data project.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

63% of data project failures are due to issues with people and culture (McKinsey, 2018)

In short, if you can get people on board, you are much more likely to have positive outcomes for your data project.

title: Q: Avoiding failure in data projects
body: According to a report from Gartner in 2018, what percentage of data projects fail. Drag the slider to your answer.
instruction: Drag the slider below and click 'Submit'

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

85% of data projects fail (Gartner, 2017)

title: There is never a lack of data, or technology.
body: There is never a lack of technology or data. Both are often seen as the “golden bullet” to solving a whole host of vaguely defined problems. In fact having too much technology and data can cause more problems, both legal and ethical. Too much data and technology becomes more challenging to manage, more disparate, siloed and not to mention aged and part of the legacy/debt of the organisation. Having the right processes and people in place to support the data and technologies and being focussed on your purpose will help ensure that technologies and data are suitable for the purpose and not there because it is easy to get both.

title: The four sections of the data ethics canvas
displayTitle: The four sections of the data ethics canvas
body: The data ethics canvas is divided into four main sections.
instruction: Click the card to reveal more

description.body: By asking you to assess the data sources, their limitations, the rights and legislative context of data collection, use, and share that apply to your sector.

By asking you to identify your reasons for using data to develop this service/product, the potential positive and negative impact on people and society, and the potential approaches to minimise negative harm.
These are consequences that you cannot control, such as political climate or global trends.
Helps you decide on the next steps: what should you prioritise, when will you iterate, do you need training, etc.

title: The Double Diamond and Data Ethics Canvas
displayTitle: The Double Diamond and Data Ethics Canvas
body: Can you identify what part of the ODI Data Ethics Canvas is best suited for which part of the Double Diamond process?
instruction: Choose an option from each dropdown list and select Submit.

_items.text: Phase 1: Discover
Phase 2: Define
Phase 3: Develop
Phase 4: Deliver

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The first diamond is all about doing the right things. By the end of this phase you should be clear on what positive impact you want to achieve and what negative impacts you need to minimise and how. This will also mean being clear on if your data sources can be used to deliver the project in phase two. Phase two is thus all about delivering the project and at this stage you will need to ensure you are engaging with people to build and maintain trust and embedded processes that mean that impacts are continually monitored.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The first diamond is all about doing the right things. By the end of this phase you should be clear on what positive impact you want to achieve and what negative impacts you need to minimise and how. This will also mean being clear on if your data sources can be used to deliver the project in phase two. Phase two is thus all about delivering the project and at this stage you will need to ensure you are engaging with people to build and maintain trust and embedded processes that mean that impacts are continually monitored.

title: Data Ethics Maturity Model
body:
As mentioned previously, tools are useless in organisations that are not set up and mature enough to make use of them. This means having clear roles and responsibilities supported by policies, processing and training. The Data Ethics Maturity Model intends to help you to assess and benchmark how widely embedded ethical data practices are across an organisation.

The purpose of the Data Ethics Maturity Model is to:

  • Allow for an initial assessment and benchmarking

  • Provide understanding of organisation areas to focus on, actions to take, and how to monitor progress, and 

  • Provide a good practical first step for practitioners to use

title: Data Ethics Maturity Model: Themes
body:
The model introduces six themes. These themes are grouped between ‘people’ and ‘policy & process’:

People

Organisational governance & internal oversight
Strategy reflects ethical data practices. Leadership with responsibility and capacity to deliver.

 

Skills & knowledge
Identifying the learning, training and sharing required.

 

Stakeholder & staff engagement
Engagement with communities reflected in or impacted by the data.

Policy and Process

Data management risk processes
Underpinning ethical collection, use and sharing of data with focus on minimising risks of harm to people.

 

Funding & procurement
Investment in and requirements for ethical data practices.

 

Legal standing & compliance
Relevant laws, regulations and social norms.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

title: The Data Ethics Canvas
body: The Data Ethics Canvas helps teams to have a guided discussion to identify the positive and negative impacts of their data project on people and society. It's a tool for anyone who collects, shares or uses data. It helps identify and manage ethical issues - in both the promotion of positive outcomes and mitigation of negative outcomes.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Putting data in data ethics
body: In relation to data, which of the following is likely to cause the biggest data ethics challenges?

_items.text: A lack of data
The quality of the data
Bias in the data
No clear rights to use the data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

There is no lack of data, in fact it is the opposite “too much data” that often leads to a greater ethical challenge. Having too much data makes it hard to manage and apply good data management principles such as quality control. A dataset can be evaluated a s high quality, but often quality does not consider bias. One of the biggest challenges arises from bias in data collection. Understanding the purpose for data collection, any targets and also the goals (or even geographic location) of the organisation that collected, stewarded the data,  will help understand if the data could be biased. 

Even the most respected research areas such as medical, have been discovered as having historical biases that mean most medical procedures are biassed toward the male anatomy.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

There is no lack of data, in fact it is the opposite “too much data” that often leads to a greater ethical challenge. Having too much data makes it hard to manage and apply good data management principles such as quality control. A dataset can be evaluated a s high quality, but often quality does not consider bias. One of the biggest challenges arises from bias in data collection. Understanding the purpose for data collection, any targets and also the goals (or even geographic location) of the organisation that collected, stewarded the data,  will help understand if the data could be biased. 

Even the most respected research areas such as medical, have been discovered as having historical biases that mean most medical procedures are biassed toward the male anatomy.

title: Embedding data ethics tools into the project lifecycle
body:
You may have come across the excellent and widely recognised double diamond model before – based on a model proposed by Béla H. Bánáthy, and popularised by the British Design Council. So perhaps it might come as no surprise that the same methodology can be applied to data to help you understand where and when it fits within a project.

The double diamond is a structured design approach to tackle challenges in two stages consisting of four phases: discover, define, develop and deliver.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Using the Data Ethics Canvas
body:
The Data Ethics Canvas is a tool for anyone who collects, shares or uses data. It helps identify and manage ethical issues – at the start of a project that uses data, and throughout.

It encourages you to ask important questions about projects that use data, and reflect on the responses. These might be:

  • What is your primary purpose for using data in this project?

  • Who could be negatively affected by this project?

The Data Ethics Canvas provides a framework to develop ethical guidance that suits any context, whatever the project’s size or scope. There is guidance and support for using the Data Ethics Canvas on the ODI website, shared under an open licence.

title: Applying the Data Ethics Maturity Model
displayTitle: Applying the Data Ethics Maturity Model
body:
Unlike the other tools, the Data Ethics Maturity Model is not intended for specific data sets. Considering data ethics at project level is good, but deep and lasting developments must happen at organisation level. This is the focus of the Data Ethics Maturity Model. The tool helps assess and benchmark how widely embedded data ethics culture and practices are across your organisation.

It provides a framework to consider current performance and future ambitions, to embed a culture of ethical data practices. This tool builds on the Open Data Institute’s Data Ethics Canvas, which helps identify and manage ethical issues within a specific project, and may be particularly helpful to Data Ethics Professionals who are working to embed a data ethics culture within their organisation.

Materials and guidance to support your use of the Data Ethics Maturity Model can be found on the ODI website, shared under an open licence.

title: Data ethics tools
body: The ODI has developed and is responsible for a series of Data Ethics tools that focus on supporting individuals and organisations in embedding data ethics practices into their projects and overarching organisational strategies.

title: Data Ethics Maturity Model: Assessment levels
body:
Across the six themes, the organisation is assessed and categorised into one of five levels:

InitialNon-existent, ad-hoc or inconsistent, with no organisational oversight.
RepeatableBecoming refined and repeatable, but only within individual teams or projects. No organisational standards.
DefinedStandards formed around internal or external best practices. Knowledge starts to be shared internally, but may still not be widely adopted.
ManagedStandards are widely adopted. Monitoring using defined metrics has begun.
OptimisingAttempting to refine and increase efficiency, and influence business sector.

title: Which scenario would like to use?
displayTitle: Which scenario would like to use?
body: Choose which scenario you would like to use for the consequence scanning activity
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: Scenario 1
Scenario 2

title: Scenario 2: Intended consequences
body:
To support your learning, we have provided the following intended and unintended consequences for your chosen case study. Please note, these are not exhaustive and there are many additional consequences that you may identify.

Your task is to review the list of intended and unintended consequences and sort them into the following categories:

  • Act: The things the core team can take forward and action immediately. Within these, prioritisation and time scales should be applied.

  • Influence: Consequences that need to be handled by other stakeholders, either within the organisation or externally, but within reachable networks.

  • Monitor: These are consequences that you cannot control, such as political climate or global trends.

There’s no right or wrong answer to these categorisations. When consequence scanning is applied to your own projects, you’ll have a much more granular understanding of what you can act upon, what you can influence and what you should monitor. For this activity, try to broaden your perspective and consider what can be reasonably assumed - this will help you to define actions in the next step.

_items.text: Increase overall profits for the firm through efficiencies in employment and service offering
Improved access to taxi services by being more elastic and available during a 24/7 operation
Support long-term effective practices by identifying peaks in service requests and usage
Develop a better service for users by offering more choice and meeting dynamic demand
Reduced supply during low usage periods, reducing carbon footprint of idling
Increased flexibility for taxi drivers and benefits in workload management

title: Scenario 1: Intended consequences
body:
To support your learning, we have provided the following intended and unintended consequences for your chosen case study. Please note, these are not exhaustive and there are many additional consequences that you may identify.

Your task is to review the list of intended and unintended consequences and sort them into the following categories:

  • Act: The things the core team can take forward and action immediately. Within these, prioritisation and time scales should be applied.

  • Influence: Consequences that need to be handled by other stakeholders, either within the organisation or externally, but within reachable networks.

  • Monitor: These are consequences that you cannot control, such as political climate or global trends.

There’s no right or wrong answer to these categorisations. When consequence scanning is applied to your own projects, you’ll have a much more granular understanding of what you can act upon, what you can influence and what you should monitor. For this activity, try to broaden your perspective and consider what can be reasonably assumed - this will help you to define actions in the next step.

_items.text: Reduction of risk from old systems, including privacy, leaks and disparities in data organisation and structure
More effect analysis and reporting across the charity
Consolidation of datasets that support more effective and efficient analysis with the potential to increase the performance of charity outputs
Simplification of workloads and data practices for all employees, with significant benefits for volunteer stakeholders
Simplification of training and feedback across user groups which reduces the amount of time and resource spent on training and support
More effective animal support and animal placement into safe homes
Reduction of misplacements of animals
Increase in pricing disparities in communities not appropriately serviced by public transport
User journeys are tracked and potentially identifiable, with risk to personal safety
Reduced services for communities in areas deemed “low demand” where drivers are encouraged to accept fares in high-demand areas
Unintended increase in pricing in cases of extreme events (e.g. local emergencies)
Increase in vehicles on the road, increase the traffic congestion and has an environmental impact
Increase in data collection and use has an increase in the risks associated with storing and processing the data
Disparities in driver experiences based on flexibility, earnings and support. Drivers are encouraged to seek high fare periods which impacts work-life balance
Users of the service are incorrectly profiled and unable to home an animal
Diverse range of internal users increases the number of data quality issues where data is manually created and input
Simplified processes and storage leads to overly complex permissions set up and provides disparate or inappropriate access to volunteer staff
Increased data breaches due to increase of activities undertaken on a single system
Reduced staff resource as efficiencies in practice have negative effect on individual workloads
Risk of data deletion of duplication of errors in transferring and interacting with data on a single system
Data held about individuals (personal or otherwise) is used to create profiles that are biassed
Increase in digital divide for colleagues who are not appropriately supported through large scale digital transformation

title: Consequence Scanning Toolkit
body: Consequence Scanning is designed as an agile practice that fits within an iterative development cycle. This is a way for organisations to consider the potential consequences of their product or service on people and society. This practice is an innovation tool that also provides an opportunity to mitigate or address potential harms or disasters before they happen.

title: Card questions
body: The questions below will help your team to share knowledge and expertise in order to map the potential impact of your work. Most importantly, these questions are designed to be asked to a varied group of stakeholders ensuring that everyone has the opportunity to input into the project.

_items.body: What are the intended and unintended consequences?
What are the positive consequences to focus on?
What are the consequences we want to mitigate?

title: Intended and unintended consequences
body:
Intended consequences describe your purpose: What are you trying to achieve? What is the positive goal of the project? Who will be positively impacted? 

Unintended consequences describe the potential side-effects of your project and focus on who could be negatively impacted or excluded from your project, impact on wider society, economy or even environment

title: Q: Publishing crime data: unintended consequences
body: What is the likelihood of the unintended consequence?

_items.text: Low
Medium
High

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Many countries have published highly detailed crime data. Although many had concerns, there has been no significant impact as a result of the data being published. People simply didn’t know what high crime was and it is more about experiences than statistics. Plus people buy houses for other reasons.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Many countries have published highly detailed crime data. Although many had concerns, there has been no significant impact as a result of the data being published. People simply didn’t know what high crime was and it is more about experiences than statistics. Plus people buy houses for other reasons.

title: Q: How would you rate the perceived negative impact?
body: How would you rate the perceived negative impact?

_items.text: Low
Medium
High

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Not being able to sell your house could cause significant harm, so the impact is at least medium, if not high.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Not being able to sell your house could cause significant harm, so the impact is at least medium, if not high.

title: Striking a balance between positive and negative impacts
body:
To assess if a potential unintended consequence is a real risk it is important to evaluate the likelihood and the severity of the impact. A common method of doing this is to complete a risk matrix and assign a risk score.

It is important to remember that while the impact of different risks could be the same, e.g. “Damage to organisation's reputation”, the likelihood and severity scores could be significantly different depending on the risk and wider context of the risk within the organisation.

It is also likely to vary widely depending on the organisation's attitude towards the risk. For example, is sharing poor quality data, which is likely most of the time, actually high in severity? Especially if you tell people the data is likely to contain errors due to the way it was collected.

title: Consequence scanning: deciding what to do
displayTitle: Consequence scanning: deciding what to do
body: Once your team has had the opportunity to explore the intended and unintended consequences and rated those highest in risk. You can then group these consequences into the following categories:
instruction: Click the card to reveal more

description.body: The things the core team can take forward and action immediately. Within these, prioritisation and time scales should be applied.
Consequences that need to be handled by other stakeholders, either within the organisation or externally, but within reachable networks.

_items.title: MONITOR
_items.body: Where do you not take any responsibility yet?

description.body: These are consequences that you cannot control, such as political climate or global trends.

title: Applying the Consequence Scanning Toolkit
body:
This is your opportunity to experience a consequence scanning workshop. To support your learning we’ve provided some pre-populated scenarios for you to consider and work through. 

Scenario Selection and Exploration
instruction: Your first task is to choose one scenario that captures your interest. Understand the case study and its objectives. Select the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Scenario 1: A charitable transformation
_items.body:
An animal charity is going through a digital transformation process. This charity supports animal care and rehoming. Therefore it holds data on the animals, the users of the service such as those who hand over animals, and those who foster or adapt, as well as data associated with volunteers, donors and broader stakeholders. 

As part of this transformation the charity wants to retire redundant platforms and consolidate all data and data processes into a single platform. This includes employee record systems, Customer Relationship Management (CRM) platforms, Volunteer Management Systems (VMS) as well as donations, animal welfare data, data supplied by local authorities and information related to internal processes and practices.

The data the charity holds includes (amongst others):

  • Financial Donors: personal details, level of involvement, etc

  • Volunteers: personal details, experience, etc

  • Adopters: potential, previous and existing. Including details of refusals and returns

  • Users: individuals who have previously handed an animal to the charity

Objective:

To reduce costs and increase efficiencies by simplifying the digital estate of the charity and reduce the redundancies in existing processes to mitigate risks. The digital transformation should maintain stakeholder privacy and maintain performance in relation to animal care.

_items.title: Scenario 2: The supply and demand of taxi services
_items.body:
A taxi firm uses data about their uses to provide personalised pricing and create a more efficient transport market where supply matches demand. The automatic pricing algorithm measures the demand in a localised area and increases the price of a fare to encourage more drivers onto the road. 

The increases in prices are temporary and applied on top of the standard fare (for example a 2x multiplier means the dynamic fare is twice that of the standard fare). To determine the dynamic pricing model the taxi firm analyses how much people are willing to pay for a certain route and uses factors such as if your phone battery is getting low, the speed which you type (including the amount of typos), walking speed and the way in which you hold your phone on any given day. 

These factors, coupled with the data about the number of rides requested, taken, cost, location and timing are all analysed together to build a predictive model.

Objective:

Dynamic pricing is intended to provide a supply and demand model that provides an effective service for customers, whilst maintaining efficient business practices.

title: Taking action on consequences
body:
Categorising the consequences into ACT, INFLUENCE and MONITOR aids in creating focused action plans for these consequences. This helps to promote the positive outcomes, but mitigate the negative potential of others. 

The next step is to plan actions that support making the consequences in these areas to be more positive than negative. Actions should be direct and focus on the on-going impact to people and society. They should also be clear on the benefit of the consequence, or the risk and what it means to be mitigated.

 

When creating action is is useful to consider the following:

  • What could this mean to the consumers of your product? Have you considered security, reliability and support?

  • What does this mean for wellbeing or relationships? Who else does your user experience the product with?

  • What does the consequence mean if it was applied across the world? What is the effect on different communities? 

  • Are there any differences between professional and personal lives? What might this mean in different geographic contexts?

 

Remember, consequence scanning is a high-level and holistic approach to evaluating your data project. Actions you define at this stage do not need to be all encompassing or solve every issue. They are to be used as an anchor point to support your future design, development and implementation.

 

We are not asking you to define your actions here, but take a moment to think about them before proceeding.

title: Data Ethics Maturity Model
body:
Unlike the other two tools, this is not intended for specific data sets, but is more overarching

Considering data ethics at project level is good, but deep and lasting developments must happen at organisation level. This is the focus of the Data

title: Data Ethics Canvas
body: For deep consideration of a project. It is divided into four areas: ‘Data’, ‘Impact’, ‘Engagement’ and ‘Process’. This is a tool to focus discussions from ideation to implementation, and considers everything from purpose to effects, as well as how to monitor and iterate.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

title: Consequence scanning toolkit
body: For a quick assessment of a project, with particular emphasis on the intended and unintended consequences on people, communities and the planet. It provides an opportunity to enhance positive consequences, and to mitigate or address potential harms from negative consequences before they happen. It considers what can be acted upon, what can be influenced, and how to monitor.
